Therefore, the most likely pulmonary physiology for this patient is an increased Aa gradient, normal surface area for diffusion, and increased diffusion distance.
Therefore, the answer is: D

Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a mental health condition that is triggered by a terrifying event — either experiencing it or witnessing it. Symptoms may include flashbacks, nightmares and severe anxiety, as well as uncontrollable thoughts about the event. The symptoms may be severe enough to impact a person's ability to function in daily life. PTSD can occur in all people, in people of any ethnicity, nationality or culture, and any age. PTSD was first brought to public attention in relation to war veterans, but it can result from a variety of traumatic incidents, such as a car accident, sexual assault, childhood trauma, or natural disaster. People with PTSD have intense, disturbing thoughts and feelings related to their experience that last long after the traumatic event has ended. They may relive the event through flashbacks or nightmares; they may feel sadness, fear or anger; and they may feel detached or estranged from other people. People with PTSD may avoid situations or people that remind them of the traumatic event, and they may have strong negative reactions to something as ordinary as a loud noise or an accidental touch. Therefore, the answer is: D

The patient is exhibiting symptoms of rheumatic fever, which is a complication of untreated or inadequately treated streptococcal pharyngitis. Rheumatic fever is an inflammatory disease that can affect multiple body systems, including the joints, heart, brain, and skin. The symptoms of rheumatic fever typically develop 2-4 weeks after a throat infection with group A Streptococcus. The painless subcutaneous nodules on the back of the wrist, the outside elbow, and the front of the knees are called Aschoff bodies, which are a hallmark of rheumatic fever. The inflammation in the joints of the lower extremities is called arthritis, which is another common symptom of rheumatic fever. Chorea is a symptom of rheumatic fever that is characterized by involuntary, rapid, and uncoordinated movements. It typically affects the arms, legs, and face and can be associated with emotional distress. Chorea can occur in up to 25% of patients with rheumatic fever and is more common in females than males. Therefore, the answer is: C

Question: A 67-year-old man with peripheral neuropathy comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after the results of serum protein electrophoresis showed monoclonal gammopathy. Options: A: CD8+ T lymphocytes	B: Bone marrow-derived macrophages	C: CD4+ T lymphocytes	D: Natural killer cells	E: Band neutrophils
D

The immune cells that lyse abnormal cells without the need for opsonization, priming, or prior activation are natural killer cells (NK cells). NK cells are a type of lymphocyte that are part of the innate immune system. They are able to recognize and destroy abnormal cells, such as cancer cells or virus-infected cells, without the need for prior exposure or immunization. NK cells are able to recognize and destroy abnormal cells by binding to receptors on the surface of the target cell. This binding triggers the release of cytotoxic granules, which contain proteins that are able to kill the target cell. NK cells are also able to secrete cytokines, which can help to activate other immune cells and enhance the immune response. Therefore, the answer is: D

Question: A 53-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter because of a 1-day history of confusion. The daughter reports that her mother has been acting strange for the past day, including being disoriented and talking nonsense. The patient has a

Natural killer (NK) cells are a type of white blood cell that play a crucial role in the immune system by recognizing and destroying abnormal cells, such as cancer cells or virus-infected cells. NK cells are part of the innate immune system and do not require prior exposure to a specific antigen in order to be activated. Instead, NK cells recognize abnormal cells through a process called "missing self-recognition." This means that NK cells can recognize and kill cells that have lost or downregulated certain surface molecules, such as major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules. MHC molecules are proteins that are expressed on the surface of all cells and are responsible for presenting antigens to T cells. Downregulation of MHC molecules can occur in cancer cells or virus-infected cells as a way to evade detection by the immune system. NK cells recognize this downregulation of MHC molecules as a sign of abnormality and will attack and kill the abnormal cell. Therefore, the answer is: D

The most definitive treatment for this patient would be systematic desensitization. This is a form of exposure therapy that involves gradually exposing the patient to the feared stimulus in a controlled and safe environment, with the goal of reducing the fear response over time. The patient would be gradually exposed to the feared stimulus, such as dogs, starting with images or videos of dogs and gradually working up to real-life exposure to dogs. E

The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is papillary carcinoma. Papillary carcinoma is the most common type of thyroid cancer and typically presents as a solitary nodule that is fixed to the surrounding tissues and nontender. It is also associated with normal thyroid function, as indicated by the normal TSH and negative antithyroid antibodies. Endemic goiter is a non-neoplastic enlargement of the thyroid gland that is typically caused by iodine deficiency and is not associated with a solitary nodule. Follicular carcinoma is another type of thyroid cancer that can present as a solitary nodule, but it is less common than papillary carcinoma. Graves' disease is an autoimmune disorder that causes the thyroid gland to become overactive and produce excess thyroid hormone. It is not typically associated with a solitary nodule. Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder that causes the thyroid gland to become underactive and produce insufficient thyroid hormone. It is not typically associated with a solitary nodule. Therefore, the answer is: E

Question: A 67-year-old white man presents to his primary care provider for an annual examination. He notes a pink bump that has rapidly developed on his forehead over the last month. In the past, he has had significant sun exposure including multiple blistering sunburns. The physical examination reveals a 2 cm dome-shaped plaque with a central keratin plug (as shown in the image). Excisional biopsy of the lesion reveals an exophytic nodule with central invagination, full of keratin. Keratinocyte atypia is minimal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Options: A: Keratoacanthoma	B: Basal cell carcinoma	C: Seborrheic keratosis	D: Molluscum contagiosum	E: Kaposi's sarcoma
A

Keratoacanthoma (KA) is a benign epithelial tumor of the skin that is commonly mistaken for squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). KA is a rapidly growing, dome-shaped nodule that is usually less than 2 cm in diameter. It is characterized by a central keratin plug, also known as a keratinous core. The keratin plug is formed by the accumulation of keratin, which is a protein that is produced by the cells of the epidermis. KA is most commonly found on sun-exposed areas of the skin, such as the face, neck, and arms. It is more common in older individuals and in those with a history of significant sun exposure. The diagnosis of KA is based on the clinical appearance of the lesion and the results of a skin biopsy. The treatment of KA typically involves surgical excision or destruction of the lesion. In some cases, topical therapies or cryotherapy may be used. Therefore, the answer is: A

Question: Eight weeks after starting a new weight-loss medication, a 43-year-old woman with obesity comes to the physician because of greasy diarrhea, excessive belching, and flatulence. She also complains of progressively worsening night-time vision. She has had no fever, chills, or vomiting. Physical examination shows dry, scaly skin on her extremities and face. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of the drug she is taking?
Options: A: Stimulation of monoamine neurotransmitter release	B: Inhibition of serotonin reuptake	C: Stimulation of norepinephrine release	D: Inhibition of lipase	E: Secretion of glucose-dependent insulin
D

Orlistat is a medication that is used to treat obesity. It works by inhibiting lipase, an enzyme that breaks down fats in the digestive tract. This reduces the amount of fat that is absorbed from the diet, which can help to promote weight loss. The patient's symptoms of greasy diarrhea, excessive belching, and flatulence are common side effects of orlistat, as it can cause undigested fat to pass through the digestive system and be excreted in the stool. The patient's night-time vision problems are also a known side effect of orlistat, as it can interfere with the absorption of fat-soluble vitamins such as vitamin A, which is important for vision. Therefore, the answer is: D

"Impact of pulmharkimab on asthma control and cardiovascular disease progression in patients with coronary artery disease and comorbid asthma
Introduction:
Active asthma has been found to be associated with a more than two-fold increase in the risk of myocardial infarction, even after adjusting for cardiovascular risk factors. It has been suggested that the inflammatory mediators and accelerated atherosclerosis characterizing systemic inflammation may increase the risk of both asthma and cardiovascular disease. This study evaluated the efficacy of the novel IL-1 inhibitor pulmharkimab in improving asthma and cardiovascular disease progression.
Methods:
In this double-blind, randomized controlled trial, patients (N=1200) with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction in the past 2 years, and a diagnosis of comorbid adult-onset asthma were recruited from cardiology clinics at a large academic medical center in Philadelphia, PA. Patients who were immunocompromised or had a history of recurrent infections were excluded.
Patients were subsequently randomly assigned a 12-month course of pulmharkimab 75 mg/day, pulmharkimab 150 mg/day, or a placebo, with each group containing 400 participants. All participants were included in analysis and analyzed in the groups to which they were randomized regardless of medication adherence. Variables measured included plaque volume, serum LDL-C levels, FEV1/FVC ratio, and Asthma Control Questionnaire (ACQ) scores, which quantified the severity of asthma symptoms. Plaque volume was determined by ultrasound.
Analyses were performed from baseline to month 12.
Results:
At baseline, participants in the two groups did not differ by age, gender, race, plaque volume, serum LDL-C levels, FEV1/FVC ratio, and ACQ scores (p > 0.05 for all). A total of 215 participants (18%) were lost to follow-up. At 12-month follow-up, the groups contained the following numbers of participants:
Pulmharkimab 75 mg/d: 388 participants
Pulmharkimab 150 mg/d: 202 participants
Placebo: 395 participants
Table 1: Association between pulmharkimab and both pulmonary and cardiovascular outcomes. Models were adjusted for sociodemographic variables and medical comorbidities. All outcome variables were approximately normally distributed.

FEV1/FVC ratio, change from baseline 0.29 ± 2.21 0.34 ± 5.54 -0.22 ± 3.21 0.27
ACQ scores, change from baseline 0.31 ± 1.22 0.46 ± 3.25 0.12 ± 1.33 0.43
Conclusion:
Pulmharkimab may be effective in reducing plaque volume but does not lead to improved asthma control in patients with a history of myocardial infarction and comorbid asthma.

Question: A 40-year-old patient is brought into the emergency department after suffering a motor vehicle crash where he was pinned underneath his motorcycle for about 30 minutes before a passerby called 911. A

Compartment syndrome is a condition in which increased pressure within a closed fascial space (compartment) compromises the circulation and function of the tissues within that space. The most common cause of compartment syndrome is trauma, but it can also be caused by infection, bleeding, or ischemia. Symptoms of compartment syndrome include pain, numbness, paresthesias, and paralysis. If left untreated, compartment syndrome can lead to tissue necrosis and permanent damage. The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on the patient's history and physical examination. Laboratory studies are not typically needed. Treatment for compartment syndrome involves emergent fasciotomy, which is a surgical procedure in which the fascia is incised to relieve the pressure within the compartment. This allows for the restoration of blood flow to the affected tissues and prevents further damage. Therefore, the answer is: A

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder that causes muscle weakness and fatigue. It is caused by antibodies that block the transmission of nerve impulses to muscles. The symptoms typically worsen with activity and improve with rest. The most common symptoms include drooping eyelids, double vision, difficulty swallowing, and weakness in the arms and legs. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical symptoms, physical examination, and laboratory tests. Treatment includes medications that improve muscle strength and reduce fatigue, as well as surgery to remove the thymus gland, which is involved in the production of antibodies. Myasthenia gravis is a chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue. The symptoms typically worsen with physical activity and improve with rest. The muscle weakness can affect various muscle groups, including the muscles of the face, neck, and limbs. The symptoms may also fluctuate over time, with periods of improvement and worsening. The exact cause of myasthenia gravis is not fully understood, but it is thought to be caused by an autoimmune response in which the body's immune system attacks the neuromuscular junction, the site where nerve impulses are transmitted to muscles. This attack results in the disruption of the communication between the nerves and muscles, leading to muscle weakness. Myasthenia gravis can be treated with medications, such as cholinesterase inhibitors and immunosuppressants, as well as with thymectomy, a surgical procedure to remove the thymus gland. Therefore, the answer is: D

Question: A 65-year-old male presents to his pulmonologist for a follow-up visit. He has a history of chronic progressive dyspnea over the past five years. B

The drug in question is likely N-acetylcysteine (NAC), which is a mucolytic agent used to treat respiratory conditions such as chronic bronchitis, asthma, and pulmonary fibrosis. The primary mechanism of action of NAC in the lungs is the reduction in airway surface tension. NAC is a mucolytic agent, which means that it breaks down the disulfide bonds in mucus, making it less viscous and easier to expectorate. This reduction in airway surface tension improves airflow and reduces the work of breathing. Therefore, the answer is: E

Question: A 37-year-old woman presents to your office with heartburn. Following an extensive workup, you diagnose her with a duodenal ulcer secondary to H. pylori infection. Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) that is commonly used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and peptic ulcers. It works by inhibiting the H+/K+ ATPase pump in the parietal cells of the stomach, which is responsible for secreting hydrochloric acid into the stomach. By blocking this pump, omeprazole reduces the amount of acid produced by the stomach, which can help to alleviate symptoms of heartburn and prevent the formation of new ulcers. PPIs work by inhibiting the activity of the H+/K+-ATPase pump, which is responsible for the secretion of hydrochloric acid (HCl) in the stomach. Rigor mortis is a post-mortem change that occurs in the muscles of a dead body, characterized by stiffness and rigidity. It is caused by the depletion of intracellular calcium, which leads to the formation of cross-bridges between actin and myosin filaments in the muscle fibers. This cross-bridging causes the muscle fibers to contract and become stiff, resulting in the characteristic rigidity of rigor mortis. The depletion of intracellular calcium is thought to be caused by a combination of factors, including the breakdown of cell membranes, the release of calcium from intracellular stores, and the inhibition of calcium uptake by the sarcoplasmic reticulum. The process of rigor mortis begins shortly after death and reaches its peak within 12-24 hours. After this time, the body begins to decompose, and the rigidity of the muscles gradually decreases. Therefore, the answer is: E

46,XY disorders of sex development (DSD) are a group of congenital conditions in which individuals with XY chromosomes do not develop typical male or female sex characteristics. One of the most common types of 46,XY DSD is complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (CAIS), which occurs when the body is unable to respond to the effects of testosterone. Individuals with CAIS are genetically male, but they have a female appearance and develop female secondary sex characteristics during puberty. Treatment for CAIS typically involves hormone replacement therapy with estrogen and progestin to induce puberty and promote the development of female secondary sex characteristics. She has been breastfeeding the infant but feels the latch has been poor and is unsure how much milk he has been consuming but feels it is not enough. A lactation consult was called for the patient and it was noted that despite proper instruction the observed latch was still poor. When asked the mother stated that the baby is currently making stools 2 times per day. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of the patient's presentation?
Options: A: Breast milk jaundice	B: Breastfeeding jaundice	C: Sepsis	D: Crigler-Najjar syndrome	E: Physiologic hyperbilirubinemia
B

Breastfeeding jaundice is a condition that occurs in breastfed infants who are not getting enough milk. It is caused by a combination of factors, including insufficient milk intake, inadequate milk production, and poor latch. This can lead to an accumulation of bilirubin, a yellow pigment that is produced when the body breaks down old red blood cells. The bilirubin accumulates in the infant's bloodstream and is excreted through the liver, which can cause the skin and eyes to appear yellow. Breastfeeding jaundice is a common condition that affects many breastfed infants. It is usually mild and resolves on its own within a few days to a week. Treatment may include increasing the frequency of breastfeeding, providing supplemental formula, and using a breast pump to increase milk production. Therefore, the answer is: B

Question: A 26-year-old female complains of frequent, large volume urination. This negatively affects her sleep, as she has to frequently wake up at night to urinate. Options: A: Hypothalamic over-production of antidiuretic hormone (ADH)	B: Decreased production of ADH	C: ADH resistance in the renal collecting ducts	D: Increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion	E: Increased aquaporin expression in the renal collecting ducts
C

Lithium-induced diabetes insipidus is a condition that occurs when the kidneys are unable to concentrate urine properly, leading to increased urine production and frequent urination. This is due to a resistance to the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) in the kidneys, which normally helps to regulate the amount of water that is reabsorbed from the urine. The increased urine production leads to an increase in the amount of water that is excreted, resulting in a decrease in the concentration of solutes in the urine. This is reflected in the low urine osmolality. The increased urine production also leads to an increase in the amount of water that is lost from the body, which can lead to dehydration and an increase in thirst. This is reflected in the increased serum osmolality, which is a measure of the concentration of solutes in the blood. Therefore, the answer is: C

Question: A 19-year-old Caucasian male presents to your office with hypopigmented skin. He undergoes a skin biopsy and is found to have an absence of melanocytes in the epidermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Options: A: Tinea versicolor	B: Albinism	C: Vitiligo	D: Solar lentigo	E: Melanoma
C

Vitiligo is an autoimmune condition that results in the loss of melanocytes, which are the cells that produce melanin, the pigment that gives skin its color. This can lead to the development of patches of depigmented skin. The exact cause of vitiligo is not known, but it is believed to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Vitiligo can affect people of all ages and ethnicities, but it is more common in people with a family history of the condition. There is no cure for vitiligo, but there are treatments that can help to improve the appearance of the skin. These may include topical creams, light therapy, and surgery. Therefore, the answer is: C

Albinism is a genetic condition characterized by a lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes. It is caused by mutations in genes that are involved in the production of melanin, which is responsible for skin, hair, and eye color. People with albinism have very fair skin, white or light-colored hair, and blue or gray eyes. They may also have vision problems, such as reduced visual acuity and nystagmus (involuntary eye movements). There are several types of albinism, including oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) and ocular albinism (OA). OCA affects the skin, hair, and eyes, while OA only affects the eyes. Albinism is a rare condition that affects people of all races and ethnicities. It is an autosomal recessive trait, which means that both parents must carry the mutated gene in order for their child to have albinism. There is no cure for albinism, but there are treatments available to help manage the symptoms. People with albinism may need to use sunscreen and protective clothing to prevent sunburns, and they may need to wear glasses or contact lenses to correct vision problems. They may also benefit from genetic counseling to understand the inheritance pattern of the condition and the risk of passing it on to their children. Therefore, the answer is: B

Answer: The most appropriate next step in the management of this patient is to prescribe a prophylactic migraine medication. Prophylactic medications are used to prevent migraine attacks from occurring. They are typically used in patients who have frequent migraine attacks (more than 4 per month) or in patients who have migraine attacks that are severe and difficult to treat with acute medications. Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne viral infection that is endemic in many tropical and subtropical regions of the world. It is caused by the dengue virus and is transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito. The symptoms of dengue fever typically appear 4-10 days after the bite of an infected mosquito and can include fever, headache, muscle and joint pain, rash, and eye pain. In some cases, dengue fever can progress to a more severe form known as dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF), which is characterized by severe bleeding and a drop in blood pressure. DHF is a serious complication of dengue fever that can lead to death if not treated promptly. Question: A researcher is interested in identifying the most effective treatment for uncomplicated urinary tract infections (UTI) in women between the ages of 18 and 50. Of 200 consecutive women who present to the emergency room for such a UTI, 50 are randomized to each of the following: nitrofurantoin 100 mg every 12 hours for 5 days, nitrofurantoin 100 mg every 12 hours for 7 days, cefpodoxime 100 mg every 12 hours for 5 days, and cefpodoxime 100 mg every 12 hours for 7 days. The measured outcomes include progression to pyelonephritis, positive urine culture on day 7 after initiation of treatment, and likelihood of re-presenting to the emergency room for another UTI within 90 days. Which of the following best describes this type of study?
Options: A: Parallel study	B: Factorial design study	C: Non-crossover study	D: Between patient study	E: Cluster randomized trial
B

The study is a parallel study because each of the 200 women is randomly assigned to one of the four treatment groups. The outcome is measured in each of the 200 women, and the results are then compared across the four treatment groups. This is different from a factorial design study, which would involve randomly assigning women to two or more treatment groups and then measuring the outcome for each combination of treatments. This is also different from a non-crossover study, which would involve randomly assigning women to one treatment group and then measuring the outcome for that group only. It is also different from a between patient study, which would involve randomly assigning women to one treatment group and then measuring the outcome for that group only. Finally, it is different from a cluster randomized trial, which would involve randomly assigning groups of women (such as different clinics or hospitals) to different treatment groups and then measuring the outcome for each group. Therefore, the answer is: A

Question: A 23-year-old man presents with sudden loss of consciousness while pitching in a baseball game. There is no history of injury. Consciousness is regained after cardiopulmonary resuscitation. Past medical history is negative for any neurological and cardiovascular problems. Physical examination reveals a prominent A wave on the jugular venous pulse and a double apical impulse. There are no audible murmurs. An S4 is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Options: A: Dilated cardiomyopathy	B: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy	C: Aortic stenosis	D: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy	E: Restrictive cardiomyopathy
B

The most likely diagnosis is hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). HCM is a genetic disorder characterized by thickening of the walls of the heart, which can lead to obstruction of blood flow and arrhythmias. It is the most common cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes. Patients with HCM may have a prominent A wave on the jugular venous pulse, which is caused by the increased pressure in the right side of the heart. A double apical impulse is also a common finding in HCM, as the thickened walls of the heart can cause abnormal movement of the heart during contraction. An S4 is a low-frequency sound that is heard during diastole, and it is often present in patients with HCM. Therefore, the answer is: B

1. Cocaine use can lead to acute kidney injury, which can cause a decrease in glomerular filtration rate and an increase in creatinine levels.
2. Binge drinking can lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances, which can cause a decrease in blood pressure and an increase in serum potassium levels.
3. Streptococcal infections, such as impetigo, can cause an immune response that can lead to an increase in white blood cell count and an increase in serum glucose levels.
4. Intestinal IgA deficiency can lead to an increase in serum IgA levels, which can cause an increase in the white blood cell count and a decrease in the hematocrit.
5. Myoglobin toxicity can lead to rhabdomyolysis, which can cause an increase in serum creatinine levels and an increase in serum potassium levels.
6. Protein deposition can lead to a decrease in serum albumin levels, which can cause an increase in serum globulin levels and a decrease in the hematocrit.
Therefore, the answer is: E

At the hospital, the vital signs include: temperature 40.0°C (104.0°F), blood pressure 140/80 mm Hg, heart rate 98/min, and respiratory rate 28/min. On physical exam, he is thin and poorly kept. His clothes appear dirty. Small scars are visible in the decubitus region of both arms. The lung sounds are equal with bilateral crackles, and heart auscultation reveals a systolic murmur that radiates to the left axilla. Petechiae are seen on the hard palate and palms of his hands. A chest X-ray and blood cultures are ordered. What is the most likely organism causing his symptoms?
Options: A: Streptococci viridans	B: Enterococci	C: Staphylococcus aureus	D: Aspergillus fumigatus	E: Staphylococcus epidermidis
C

Question: A 20-year-old male college student presents to the emergency room at 4 AM in the morning with complaints of abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea for the past 2 hours. Screening ultrasound reveals a new liver nodule, and follow up CT demonstrates a 2 cm right hepatic lobe lesion with enhancement in the arterial phase. Options: A: Proceed with liver biopsy	B: Refer for surgical resection	C: Refer for radiofrequency ablation	D: Treat with sorafenib	E: Observe and get follow-up imaging in 3 months

The patient should be observed and have follow-up imaging in 3 months. Hepatic nodules are common in patients with cirrhosis and are classified as benign or malignant based on their appearance on imaging studies. Benign lesions, such as hemangiomas, regenerative nodules, and dysplastic nodules, are common in patients with cirrhosis and do not require further workup. Malignant lesions, such as hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), are less common but require further evaluation and treatment. The patient should be observed and have follow-up imaging in 3 months to determine whether the lesion is growing or changing in appearance. Question: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for evaluation of progressively worsening swelling around the eyes. He has no history of major medical illness. He had a sore throat and cough 2 weeks ago that resolved spontaneously. Physical examination shows moderate periorbital edema and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities bilaterally. A kidney biopsy specimen shows effacement of the podocytes on electron microscopy. Which of the following is most likely to be found on urinalysis?
Options: A: Hyaline casts and immunoglobulins	B: Red blood cell casts and acanthocytes	C: Fatty casts and albumin	D: White blood cell casts and eosinophils	E: Granular casts and tubular epithelial cells
C

The patient's history and physical examination findings are consistent with nephrotic syndrome, which is a condition characterized by proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema. The effacement of the podocytes on electron microscopy is a characteristic finding in minimal change disease (MCD), which is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. In MCD, there is a loss of the normal architecture of the podocytes, which are specialized cells that form the glomerular filtration barrier. This can lead to increased permeability of the glomerular membrane and proteinuria. On urinalysis, patients with MCD typically have large amounts of protein in the urine, which can be seen as a proteinuria of 3+ or greater. The proteinuria in MCD is characterized by a loss of albumin, which is the most abundant protein in the blood. Therefore, urinalysis is likely to show increased albumin excretion in the urine. Therefore, the answer is: C

Gout is a type of arthritis that is caused by the accumulation of uric acid crystals in the joints, tendons, and other tissues. Uric acid is a waste product that is produced by the body during the breakdown of purines, which are found in certain foods such as red meat, seafood, and alcohol. In people with gout, the body either produces too much uric acid or is unable to excrete it properly, leading to an accumulation of uric acid crystals in the body. These crystals can cause inflammation and pain in the affected joints, which is a characteristic symptom of gout. The most common joint affected by gout is the big toe, which can become red, swollen, and tender. Gout is more common in men than women and is often associated with other conditions such as high blood pressure, diabetes, and obesity. Treatment for gout typically involves medications to reduce inflammation and pain, as well as lifestyle changes to help prevent future attacks. Therefore, the answer is: D

Question: A 24-year-old woman delivers a baby at term. The Apgar counts are 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Thirty minutes after delivery, the mother’s blood pressure drops to 80/60 mm Hg and her pulse is 124/min. On physical examination, her distal extremities are clammy and cold, and the uterus is boggy. Aggressive fluid resuscitation is initiated. After administering 4 units of IV fluids and 4 units of whole blood, her vitals stabilize. The next morning, she says she is unable to lactate when she tries to breastfeed her child. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the failure of lactation in this patient?
Options: A: Pituitary tumor	B: Postpartum blues	C: Remains of placenta in uterus	D: Pituitary infarction	E: Pituitary hemorrhage
D

# Discussion
Pituitary infarction is a rare but potentially serious complication of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). PPH is a leading cause of maternal morbidity and mortality worldwide, and it is defined as a blood loss of more than 500 mL within 24 hours after delivery. Pituitary infarction can occur when there is a sudden decrease in blood flow to the pituitary gland, which can lead to ischemia and tissue damage. This can result in a range of symptoms, including headache, nausea, vomiting, visual disturbances, and lactation failure. Lactation failure is a common symptom of pituitary infarction, as the pituitary gland plays a crucial role in the production of hormones that are necessary for lactation. These hormones include prolactin, which is responsible for stimulating milk production, and oxytocin, which is responsible for the contraction of the milk ducts and the release of milk. Therefore, the answer is: D

# Discussion

## Rifampin and oral contraceptive pills
Rifampin is a potent inducer of CYP3A4, an enzyme that metabolizes many drugs, including oral contraceptive pills. This can lead to decreased levels of contraceptive hormones in the bloodstream, making them less effective at preventing pregnancy. Rifampin also alters the normal gastrointestinal flora, which can lead to a decrease in the enterohepatic circulation of estrogens, further reducing their effectiveness. Estrogens undergo enterohepatic circulation, which is a process by which they are absorbed from the gut, metabolized by the liver, and then reabsorbed into the gut. Rifampin alters the normal gastrointestinal flora, which can lead to a decrease in the enterohepatic circulation of estrogens, resulting in lower levels of estrogen in the bloodstream and potentially reducing the effectiveness of combination oral contraceptive pills. Therefore, the patient should use additional contraception, such as condoms, while taking rifampin.

C

Increased production of nitric oxide is the most likely explanation for this finding because nitric oxide is produced by vascular endothelial cells and plays a role in regulating vascular tone. The decreased concentration of arginine in the vascular endothelial cells suggests that there may be increased production of nitric oxide, which can lead to vasodilation and decreased blood pressure. Therefore, the answer is: C

The peripheral pulses being bounding suggests that there is an increased volume of blood flowing through the heart and the great vessels, which can lead to congestive heart failure if left untreated. The most appropriate treatment for PDA in a 2-day-old boy is to monitor the patient closely and manage any symptoms of heart failure, such as respiratory distress or poor feeding. If the PDA is large and causing significant symptoms, it may be necessary to treat the patient with a medication called indomethacin. Indomethacin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can help to close the PDA by causing the blood vessel to constrict. Question: A newborn is found to be extremely cyanotic immediately after birth. He then develops progressive respiratory failure and is admitted to the neonatal ICU. Options: A: Coarctation of the aorta	B: Persistent truncus arteriosus	C: Tetralogy of Fallot	D: Transposition of great vessels	E: Tricuspid atresia
D

The newborn's condition is most likely caused by tetralogy of Fallot, which is a congenital heart defect that affects the structure of the heart and the blood vessels that carry blood to the lungs. Tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by four main features: a ventricular septal defect (a hole between the lower chambers of the heart), pulmonary stenosis (narrowing of the pulmonary artery), an overriding aorta (the aorta is located directly over the ventricular septal defect), and right ventricular hypertrophy (thickening of the muscle wall of the right ventricle). These abnormalities can lead to a decrease in blood flow to the lungs and an increase in blood flow to the body, which can cause cyanosis (a bluish discoloration of the skin) and other symptoms. The newborn's symptoms of progressive respiratory failure and a loud S2 heart sound are consistent with tetralogy of Fallot. Therefore, the answer is: C

Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart defect that is characterized by four abnormalities: a ventricular septal defect (a hole in the wall between the right and left ventricles of the heart), an overriding aorta (the aorta is located directly over the ventricular septal defect), pulmonary stenosis (narrowing of the pulmonary valve or the arteries that carry blood from the heart to the lungs), and right ventricular hypertrophy (thickening of the muscle wall of the right ventricle). These abnormalities can lead to cyanosis (a bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes) and respiratory failure. The diagnosis of tetralogy of Fallot is based on a combination of physical examination, imaging studies (such as echocardiography), and other tests. The treatment for tetralogy of Fallot typically involves surgery to repair the heart defects. Therefore, the answer is: C

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a congenital heart defect that involves four anatomical abnormalities: a ventricular septal defect (VSD), right ventricular hypertrophy, an overriding aorta, and a narrowing of the pulmonary outflow tract. These abnormalities result in an imbalance of blood flow between the lungs and the body, leading to cyanosis. A single loud S2 heart sound and a machine-like murmur at the left upper sternal border are typical findings in TOF. An enlarged "egg-shaped" heart on radiography is also a common finding in TOF. Atrial septostomy is a palliative procedure that is sometimes performed in infants with TOF to increase the amount of blood flow to the lungs. The definitive treatment for TOF is surgical correction, which involves closing the VSD and widening the narrowed pulmonary outflow tract. Therefore, the answer is: C

Overriding aorta: The aorta is positioned directly over the ventricular septal defect (VSD), allowing oxygenated blood from the left ventricle to flow into the right ventricle and then into the pulmonary artery. 3. Ventricular septal defect (VSD): A hole in the septum between the right and left ventricles, allowing oxygenated blood from the left ventricle to mix with deoxygenated blood in the right ventricle. 4. Right ventricular hypertrophy: The right ventricle becomes enlarged and thickened in response to the increased workload of pumping blood through the pulmonary valve. Other symptoms may include hoarseness, difficulty swallowing, and a feeling of fullness in the neck. The condition is often associated with other autoimmune conditions, such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis and Graves' disease. Answer: Sumatriptan is a selective serotonin receptor agonist that is used to treat migraines. It works by binding to the serotonin receptors in the brain, which leads to the constriction of blood vessels and the inhibition of the release of pain-causing substances, such as substance P and calcitonin gene-related peptide. Chikungunya is a viral infection that is transmitted by mosquitoes and is endemic in many tropical and subtropical regions of the world, including Southeast Asia. The virus is spread by the Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes, which are found in many parts of the world, including Southeast Asia. Symptoms of chikungunya include fever, headache, joint pain, and rash. The virus can cause severe joint pain that can last for several weeks or months. Chikungunya is diagnosed based on clinical symptoms and laboratory testing. The most common method of diagnosis is a blood test that detects the presence of the virus in the bloodstream. Other diagnostic tests, such as a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test or an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), can also be used to confirm the diagnosis. There is no specific treatment for chikungunya, but supportive care, such as rest and pain relief medication, can help to relieve symptoms. Prevention of chikungunya involves avoiding mosquito bites and reducing the risk of mosquito breeding by eliminating standing water and using insect repellent. Therefore, the answer is: A

Which of the following medications is most appropriate in the management of this patient?
Options: A: Pyridostigmine	B: Physostigmine	C: Edrophonium	D: Hydrocortisone	E: Azathioprine
A

Pyridostigmine is a medication that is used to treat myasthenia gravis, a neuromuscular disorder that causes muscle weakness and fatigue. Pyridostigmine works by inhibiting the breakdown of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter that is responsible for muscle contraction. By increasing the amount of acetylcholine available at the neuromuscular junction, pyridostigmine can improve muscle strength and reduce the symptoms of myasthenia gravis. Therefore, the answer is: A

Question: Background:
Some patients with severe asthma have frequent exacerbations associated with persistent eosinophilic inflammation despite continuous treatment with high-dose inhaled glucocorticoids with or without oral glucocorticoids.
Methods:
In this randomized, double-blind clinical trial we assigned 576 patients with recurrent asthma exacerbations and evidence of eosinophilic inflammation despite high doses of inhaled glucocorticoids to one of three study groups. Patients were assigned to receive mepolizumab, a humanized monoclonal antibody against interleukin-5, which was administered as either a 75-mg intravenous dose or a 100-mg subcutaneous dose or placebo every 4 weeks for 32 weeks. The primary outcome was the rate of exacerbations. Other outcomes included the forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) and scores on the St. George’s Respiratory Questionnaire (SGRQ) and the 5-item Asthma Control Questionnaire (ACQ-5).
Results:
The rate of exacerbations was reduced by 47% (95% confidence interval [CI], 29 to 61) among patients receiving intravenous mepolizumab and by 53% (95% CI, 37 to 65) among those receiving subcutaneous mepolizumab, as compared with those receiving placebo (p<0.001 for both comparisons). Exacerbations necessitating an emergency department visit or hospitalization were reduced by 32% in the group receiving intravenous mepolizumab and by 61% in the group receiving subcutaneous mepolizumab. At week 32, the mean increase from baseline in FEV1 was 100 ml greater in patients receiving intravenous mepolizumab than in those receiving placebo (p=0.02) and 98 ml greater in patients receiving subcutaneous mepolizumab than in those receiving placebo (p=0.03). The improvement from baseline in the SGRQ score was 6.4 points and 7.0 points greater in the intravenous and subcutaneous mepolizumab groups, respectively than in the placebo group, and the improvement in the ACQ-5 score was 0.42 points and 0.44 points greater in the two mepolizumab groups, respectively than in the placebo group (p<0.001 for all comparisons).
Conclusions:

Question: An 11-year-old boy presents to your office with pitting edema and proteinuria exceeding 3.5g in 24 hours. You suspect that this patient has experienced a loss of polyanions in his glomerular basement membranes. Which of the following findings would confirm your diagnosis?

Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by a loss of polyanions in the glomerular basement membrane, leading to increased permeability and proteinuria. The presence of WBC casts in the urine is a sign of glomerular inflammation, which is not typically seen in nephrotic syndrome. The presence of RBC casts in the urine is a sign of glomerular injury, which is not typically seen in nephrotic syndrome. Selective albuminuria is a type of proteinuria in which only albumin is lost in the urine, which is not typically seen in nephrotic syndrome. The presence of negatively birefringent crystals in the urine is a sign of oxalate crystals, which are not typically seen in nephrotic syndrome. Bence-Jones proteinuria is a type of proteinuria in which Bence-Jones proteins, which are abnormal immunoglobulin light chains, are present in the urine. The pathogenesis of β-thalassemia involves a point mutation in the gene that encodes for the β-globin chain of hemoglobin. This breakdown of hemoglobin leads to the release of free iron, which can cause damage to the red blood cells and other tissues. Question: A multi-specialty physician practice is meeting to determine which compensation scheme would best serve the practice and its patient population. Which of the following are true in regards to physician compensation?
Options: A: Capitation poses the least financial risk to physicians	B: Fee-for-service pays physicians a set amount of money per unit time for every patient under their care	C: Fee-for-service may incentivize physicians to increase healthcare utilization irrespective of quality	D: Fee-for-service poses the most amount of financial risk to physicians	E: Capitation may provide perverse incentives to decrease preventive medicine visits
C

1) Capitation is a form of physician compensation in which physicians are paid a fixed amount of money per patient per unit time, regardless of the number of services provided. This can incentivize physicians to decrease healthcare utilization, as they will not be paid more for providing more services. However, this can also lead to perverse incentives to decrease preventive medicine visits, as these visits are often not billable under capitation.
2) Fee-for-service is a form of physician compensation in which physicians are paid a set amount of money for every service they provide. This can incentivize physicians to increase healthcare utilization, as they will be paid more for providing more services. β-adrenergic agonists are drugs that stimulate the β-adrenergic receptors in the body. These receptors are found in various tissues, including the heart, lungs, blood vessels, and smooth muscles. When activated, they increase the production of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP), which in turn leads to a variety of physiological effects. In the blood vessels, they can cause vasodilation, which can lead to a decrease in blood pressure and an increase in heart rate. In the central nervous system, they can cause an increase in body temperature, which can lead to profuse sweating and a gradual decrease in vision over time. Therefore, the answer is: D

This article is the first of a series of sample questions that have been developed to help students prepare for the United States Medical Licensing Examination (USMLE) Step 1. # Discussion

# Background
In the last decade, the prevalence of chronic kidney disease (CKD) has increased. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), 15% of US adults, or 37 million people, are estimated to have CKD. CKD is a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease, heart failure, and stroke, and patients with CKD are at a higher risk of developing these conditions. Additionally, CKD is associated with an increased risk of death from all causes, including cardiovascular disease and infection. The progression of CKD to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) requires dialysis or kidney transplantation, which are costly and have a significant impact on the quality of life of patients. Therefore, early detection and management of CKD are crucial to prevent or delay the progression of the disease and improve patient outcomes.

These changes can lead to a decrease in the overall compliance of the respiratory system, which can make it more difficult for the patient to breathe. Therefore, the answer is: D

She adds that he vomited repeatedly  in the last couple of hours, his vomitus being brown/red in color. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), respiratory rate is 16/min, pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 100/68 mm Hg. A physical exam reveals a tense abdomen with a board like rigidity and positive rebound tenderness. An erect abdominal x-ray is ordered. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Options: A: Duodenal peptic ulcer	B: Gastric peptic ulcer	C: Pancreatitis	D: Perforated gastric peptic ulcer	E: Choledocholithiasis
D

Perforated gastric peptic ulcer is the most likely diagnosis based on the patient's symptoms and physical examination findings. The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, inability to give more information about the nature of his pain, repeated vomiting of brown/red vomitus, tense abdomen with a board-like rigidity, and positive rebound tenderness are all consistent with a perforated gastric peptic ulcer. A perforated peptic ulcer occurs when a peptic ulcer, which is a sore or erosion in the lining of the stomach or duodenum, ruptures and leaks gastric contents into the abdominal cavity. This can cause a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, as well as nausea, vomiting, and an inability to pass gas or have a bowel movement. A perforated gastric peptic ulcer is a medical emergency and requires prompt treatment to prevent serious complications. Therefore, the answer is: D

The most likely diagnosis is a perforated gastric peptic ulcer. A perforated peptic ulcer is a condition in which the ulcer in the stomach or duodenum ruptures, causing the contents of the digestive tract to leak into the abdominal cavity. This can lead to severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and other symptoms. The board-like rigidity and positive rebound tenderness on physical examination are suggestive of peritonitis, which is a common complication of a perforated peptic ulcer. The erect abdominal x-ray may show air under the diaphragm, which is a sign of perforation. Therefore, the answer is: D

Question: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of yellowish discoloration of his skin and generalized pruritus. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and scleral icterus. Urinalysis shows an elevated concentration of bilirubin and a low concentration of urobilinogen. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
Options: A: Absent UDP-glucuronosyltransferase activity	B: Increased hemoglobin breakdown	C: Increased intestinal bilirubin reabsorption	D: Defective hepatic bile excretion	E: Presence of stones within the gallbladder
D

The most likely underlying cause of these findings is defective hepatic bile excretion. Jaundice is a yellowish discoloration of the skin, sclera, and mucous membranes caused by an increase in the concentration of bilirubin in the blood. Bilirubin is a breakdown product of hemoglobin that is normally excreted by the liver. When the liver is unable to excrete bilirubin properly, it accumulates in the blood and is deposited in the skin and other tissues, causing jaundice. The most common cause of jaundice is a defect in hepatic bile excretion, which can be caused by a variety of conditions, such as viral hepatitis, alcoholic liver disease, and biliary obstruction. Therefore, the answer is: D

Liver transplantation is a complex and risky procedure that requires careful planning and management. Impairment of which of the following processes is the most likely cause of the negative tuberculin skin test seen in this patient?

The most likely cause of the negative tuberculin skin test seen in this patient is impairment of the secretion of interferon-α. Interferon-α is a cytokine that is produced by immune cells in response to infection or inflammation. It plays a critical role in the body's defense against viruses and other pathogens. In the case of tuberculosis, interferon-α is involved in the activation of macrophages, which are immune cells that engulf and destroy bacteria. The tuberculin skin test is a diagnostic test that is used to determine if a person has been exposed to the bacterium that causes tuberculosis. It involves injecting a small amount of purified protein derivative (PPD) into the skin and measuring the size of the resulting skin reaction. A positive reaction indicates that the person has been exposed to the bacterium and has developed an immune response. In this case, the patient's negative tuberculin skin test suggests that he has an impaired immune response to the bacterium, which may be due to impaired secretion of interferon-α.

The negative tuberculin skin test in this patient is most likely due to an impairment of the generation of reactive oxygen species. The generation of reactive oxygen species is an important component of the immune response to Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium that causes tuberculosis. Reactive oxygen species are produced by phagocytic cells, such as macrophages and neutrophils, as part of the oxidative burst that occurs during the killing of bacteria. The reactive oxygen species help to kill the bacteria by damaging their cell membranes and other cellular components. In this patient, it is likely that the impairment of the generation of reactive oxygen species is due to the HIV infection, which can lead to a decline in the function of the immune system. This can make it more difficult for the body to mount an effective immune response to M. tuberculosis, leading to a negative tuberculin skin test. Therefore, the answer is: E

48-hour high dose dexamethasone suppression trial is used to diagnose Cushing's syndrome. This test involves giving the patient a high dose of dexamethasone, a synthetic glucocorticoid, over a period of 48 hours. Inferior petrosal sinus sampling is a procedure used to determine the source of excess ACTH production in patients with Cushing's syndrome. It involves collecting blood samples from the inferior petrosal sinuses, which are veins that drain blood from the pituitary gland. This can help to differentiate between Cushing's syndrome caused by a pituitary tumor (Cushing's disease) and Cushing's syndrome caused by an adrenal tumor. Therefore, the answer is: C

The patient has a history of heart attack, and the symptoms he describes are consistent with heart failure. The electrocardiogram and chest X-ray are useful diagnostic tools for evaluating heart failure, but they do not provide enough information to make a definitive diagnosis. An echocardiogram is a non-invasive imaging test that uses sound waves to create images of the heart. It can provide detailed information about the structure and function of the heart, including the size and shape of the heart chambers, the thickness of the heart walls, and the movement of the heart valves. Therefore, the answer is: A

The patient's presentation is consistent with Goodpasture syndrome, also known as anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease. This is a rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the production of antibodies against the basement membrane of the glomeruli in the kidneys and the alveoli in the lungs. The diagnosis of Goodpasture syndrome is typically confirmed by a combination of clinical symptoms, laboratory tests, and imaging studies. Question: A 45-year-old male with a history of diabetes and poorly controlled hypertension presents to his primary care physician for an annual check-up. He reports that he feels well and has no complaints. He takes enalapril and metformin. His temperature is 98.8°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 155/90 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 16/min. His physician adds another anti-hypertensive medication to the patient’s regimen. One month later, the patient returns to the physician complaining of new onset lower extremity swelling. Which of the following medications was likely prescribed to this patient?
Options: A: Metoprolol	B: Verapamil	C: Nifedipine	D: Hydrochlorthiazide	E: Spironolactone
C

Hydrochlorthiazide (HCTZ) is a diuretic medication that is commonly used to treat high blood pressure. It works by increasing the excretion of sodium and water from the body, which helps to lower blood pressure. HCTZ is often prescribed as part of a combination therapy regimen for patients with hypertension who are not adequately controlled with a single medication. In this case, the patient has a history of diabetes and poorly controlled hypertension, and his physician may have added HCTZ to his regimen to help lower his blood pressure. HCTZ can cause lower extremity swelling as a side effect, which is a common concern for patients taking this medication. Therefore, the answer is: D

A cardiologist at another institution is trying to replicate the table in the abstract with a very similar study that he is conducting. After collecting data on changes in plaque volume, LDL-C levels, FEV1/FVC ratio, and ACQ scores from baseline to 12-month follow-up, he is curious if the changes in the aforementioned measurements are statistically significant. Which of the following is the most appropriate statistical method to compare the groups?"
"Impact of pulmharkimab on asthma control and cardiovascular disease progression in patients with coronary artery disease and comorbid asthma
Introduction:
Active asthma has been found to be associated with a more than two-fold increase in the risk of myocardial infarction, even after adjusting for cardiovascular risk factors. It has been suggested that the inflammatory mediators and accelerated atherosclerosis characterizing systemic inflammation may increase the risk of both asthma and cardiovascular disease. This study evaluated the efficacy of the novel IL-1 inhibitor pulmharkimab in improving asthma and cardiovascular disease progression.
Methods:
In this double-blind, randomized controlled trial, patients (N=1200) with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction in the past 2 years, and a diagnosis of comorbid adult-onset asthma were recruited from cardiology clinics at a large academic medical center in Philadelphia, PA. Patients who were immunocompromised or had a history of recurrent infections were excluded.
Patients were subsequently randomly assigned a 12-month course of pulmharkimab 75 mg/day, pulmharkimab 150 mg/day, or a placebo, with each group containing 400 participants. All participants were included in analysis and analyzed in the groups to which they were randomized regardless of medication adherence. Variables measured included plaque volume, serum LDL-C levels, FEV1/FVC ratio, and Asthma Control Questionnaire (ACQ) scores, which quantified the severity of asthma symptoms. Plaque volume was determined by ultrasound.
Analyses were performed from baseline to month 12.
Results:
At baseline, participants in the two groups did not differ by age, gender, race, plaque volume, serum LDL-C levels, FEV1/FVC ratio, and ACQ scores (p > 0.05 for all). A total of 215 participants (18%) were lost to follow-up. At 12-month follow-up, the groups contained the following numbers of participants:
Pulmharkimab 75 mg/d: 388 participants
Pulmharkimab 150 mg/d: 202 participants
Placebo: 395 participants
